Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Assessing the role of rapid evolution in trait-mediated predator effects on communities and ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predators alter ecosystems both by reducing the abundance of prey and by inducing change in species traits that influence ecosystem function. These trait-mediated predator effects on ecosystems depend on the evolution of both prey traits and the responsiveness of those traits to predation risk. The evolutionary history of predator and prey thus underlies the influence of predators on communities and ecosystems. The PIs will introduce predator cues to experimental streams containing Trinidadian guppies (Poecilia reticulata) from populations that have been isolated from predators for zero to thousands of years. Measurements of guppy behavior, metabolism, and nutrient processing will assess the influence of predators on guppy traits and the dependence of predator effects on the evolutionary history of predator and prey. Corresponding measures of invertebrate and algal communities, primary productivity, and nutrient cycling will assess how induced trait change translates into ecologically meaningful differences in stream communities and ecosystem processes.

Human-driven top-predator loss is a global threat to biodiversity and ecosystem services. Understanding the mechanisms by which predators structure natural systems is necessary to predict biodiversity and ecosystem services into an uncertain future. Recent evidence indicates that evolution in contemporary time can greatly affect the outcome of ecological processes, and the PIs will assess how rapid evolution by prey mediates the influence of predators on natural systems. One PhD student will be trained in conducting this research, and the PIs will link this research to ongoing outreach with high school biology students, using hands-on research projects to teach principles of biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The feces and excreted wastes of animals are natural fertilizers that are essential to supporting the productivity of plants and animals in many ecosystems. Without the nutrients in these wastes, many ecosystems would be less productive and less diverse. Despite the importance of animal wastes to ecological dynamics, we know relatively little about the factors that determine the rate at which animals release wastes into the environment. This knowledge gap makes it difficult to predict how environments will respond to human impacts or how humans can act to offset those impacts. The research conducted under this funding sought to understand the role of stress as an influence on the nutrients released by animals in their wastes. This research was uniquely situated to probe this question by working with the guppy (Poecilia reticulata), an animal that has long been used as a lab mouse" for understanding ecological and evolutionary trait variation and has recently been shown to affect nutrients in streams. 

Once an animal has consumed its food, the nutrients in that food can end up in two places: in the animal’s waste products, or in its tissues. An animal’s physiology determines whether food nutrients end up in waste or tissues, so studying animal physiology is essential to predicting animal wastes. In nature, changes in animal physiology are often associated with stress, and this stress is often caused by the presence of predators. In the funded research, we used this predation risk to induce stress guppies, and we then measured the change in guppy physiology and the nutrients released in their wastes. Our goal was to understand how an important natural stressor affected the nutrients released by animals and the impacts that may have on ecological dynamics. Prior to our research, other experimenters had found that grasshoppers increase their metabolism and waste production under predation risk. We sought to determine whether comparable patterns existed in fish.

To conduct our research, we collected guppies (Poecilia reticulata) from Trinidad and reared them in the lab at Cornell University, in Ithaca, NY. Using a specialized experimental design, we exposed half of the guppies to the chemicals released by a predatory fish (the pike cichlid; Crenicichla frenata). Over the course of periods ranging from a few days to several months, we tracked how much food each guppy ate, how much of that food it retained as new growth, and how much it released back into the environment as waste. We also measured the metabolic rate and tissue turnover rates of guppies to assess how much energy each guppy was using and how much work each guppy invested in rebuilding and maintaining its existing tissues each day.

We found that guppies exposed to predation risk slowed their metabolism, reduced their tissue turnover, and greatly decreased their production of wastes – especially nitrogen wastes that are mostly excreted ammonium. This result occurred in as little as 12 hours, and it lasted for as long as 6 months. This result was counter to the expected pattern from previous published studies (grasshoppers had been shown to increase nitrogen waste production under predation risk), and it was associated with a strong reduction in food consumption by guppies reared with predation risk. These predator-exposed guppies consumed less food because they were hiding in shelters that had low food availability, a pattern similar to that which we observe in nature. We suspect that the reduced metabolism, tissue turnover, and waste production by guppies under predation risk is an adaptive change that increases their retention of important nutritional compounds (especially proteins) to enable survival in safe, but low food, refuges, until the predation risk passes.
